Selecting a Mask: Do’s & Don’ts

CDC
August 28 at 2:52 PM ·

Wear a mask when you’re in public to help slow the spread of COVID-19. When selecting a mask, you have many choices. Avoid masks that are made of materials that make it too hard to breathe. Also avoid masks with valves or vents that allow virus particles to escape and masks that should be saved for healthcare workers. Wear cloth masks with two or more layers to help protect yourself and others from COVID-19.

Learn more about the do’s and don’ts of masking: https://bit.ly/30QOzQF.

We know that there are still a lot of questions out there and we're asking for just a little more patience. Things are finally ramping up around the district this week with site administration back and in training today and tomorrow. Starting next week, you should be getting notifications for opportunities to have site specific questions answered by site admin.

We do plan on having "Coffee with the Supt." tomorrow morning, so feel free to leave a question/comments below. Thanks!

post_text: Merced County Office of Education has released guidelines for the reopening of schools for the 2020-21 school year. MUHSD contributed to the plan that outlines protocols, best practices and what school will look like when students return in August #WeAreMUHSD
shared_text:
Merced County Office of Education
June 19 at 5:00 PM ·

The Merced County Office of Education, in collaboration with the 20 local school districts and the Merced County Department of Public Health, has released a document of guiding principles and planning considerations schools and districts should consider when making plans for opening the 2020-2021 school year.

The document has information on what families can expect when schools reopen, athletic guidelines, a distance learning framework, information on quarantine and contact tracing, along with information for parents about social emotional wellness and mental health.

“We have worked closely with school district superintendents and the Merced County Department of Public Health to create this guidance document,” said Dr. Steve Tietjen, Merced County Superintendent of Schools. “Making sure our students and staff are safe is our top priority and these guidelines lay out parameters where schools can operate in safe ways and our students can learn.”

The document can be viewed at www.mcoe.org/schoolguidance.

May 30 at 3:59 PM ·

Graduation time is upon us! Extraordinary times call for creative and unorthodox ways of doing things, and 2020 graduations throughout the nation are an example of this. As Atwater high schools prepare to host their versions of drive-up graduation ceremonies this coming week, we would like to remind everyone to be patient and mindful. Traffic congestion is a possibility. Atwater PD is working with school administrators to help facilitate these events. We ask motorists to please do your part and obey all traffic laws. Atwater Police will be out providing extra enforcement patrol throughout the week and weekend. A zero-tolerance policy will be in effect when it comes to dangerous and foolish behavior behind the wheel. Please slow down, obey all traffic laws and let’s help make this a safe and rememberable time for all graduates during this unprecedented time in our history.

Congratulations to MUHSD's "Certificated Employee of the Year" for the 2019-20 school year, Independence High's Samantha Johnston!

Director of Student Services Cristi Johnson says that Samantha is as dependable and motivated to see students succeed as they come.

"Samantha is willing to go the extra mile to help ANY student get the education he or she needs. She welcomes each student, no matter what their background or previous situation has been, with a fresh start at school (never holding any grudges). She is creative and flexible, and easily develops positive relationships with students. Sometimes in education we are faced with challenging students, and whenever that situation arises, I call on Samantha to help and she always does what is needed to help kids be successful." #WeAreMUHSD

"Barbara has been an exceptional educator in the Merced Union High School District for many years. She’s an enormous asset to our district."
